title: Analysis of the pheromone signaling pathway by RT-qPCR in the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Yeast cell culture and pheromone treatment
Timing: Day 1, 12–16 h to grow cells until day 2; Day 2, 4 h until sample collection
The different yeast strains are cultured in three biologically independent replicates and incubated in the presence or absence of α-factor to activate or not the pheromone signaling pathway.
Inoculate an individual yeast colony from an YPD agar plate in 3 mL of YPD medium in a 15 mL tube and incubate at 30°C while shaking at 200 rpm for 12–16 h.
After 12–16 h, dilute 2 mL of the culture (expect a starting OD600 of approximately 10) into 18 mL of fresh YPD medium (1/10 dilution) in a 100 mL Erlenmeyer flask and incubate at 30°C while shaking at 200 rpm for 2 h (expect a final OD600 of approximately 2). Problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]
Split the yeast culture into two 50 mL Erlenmeyer flask (10 mL of yeast cell culture each):
Add 150 μL of α-factor (1 mg/mL) to one of the yeast cultures (final concentration 15 μg/mL).
The other culture remains untreated.
The incubation continues at 30°C while shaking at 200 rpm for 2 h for both treated and untreated cells.
After 2 h of incubation, monitor shmoo formation by differential interference contrast microscopy (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). Problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1470-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Differential interference contrast images of representative wild-type (WT) cells in absence (top) or presence (bottom) of α-factor
In the lower panel, α-factor has triggered shmoo formation. Scale bar, 5 μM. Adapted from our recently published work (Garcia et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]) (CC BY 4.0. No changes to the figure were made).
Note: Shmoo formation is a change of cell morphology that is triggered by the activation of the pheromone signaling pathway.

Critical: Work under sterile conditions. Thaw and maintain α-factor on ice until use. Proceed with step 6 only when shmoo formation has been observed for WT cells. Problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]
Harvest yeast cells:
Centrifuge a volume corresponding to 5 OD600 units 5 min at 3000×g.
Remove supernatant, resuspend the cells using 1 mL of ice-cold sterile mqH2O and transfer to a new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
Centrifuge 1 min at 15,000×g.
Remove supernatant, snap freeze the microcentrifuge tube in liquid nitrogen and store at –80°C.
Critical: Step 6c, remove any remaining supernatant before snap freezing.
Pause point: Harvested cell pellets can be stored at –80°C for 1 month before proceeding to the purification of total RNA.
Purification of total RNA
Timing: 1 h
RNA purification using adapted steps from the manufacturer’s protocol of RNeasy Mini Kit (RNeasy Mini Handbook - (EN) - QIAGEN[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=14e7cf6e-521a-4cf7-8cbc-bf9f6fa33e24&lang=en])
Critical: An appropriate safety protocol has to be followed while handling the RLT and RW1 buffers from the RNeasy Mini Kit: both contain guanidine thiocyanate and β-ME that needs to be added to RLT buffer before use. Wear lab coat, goggles, gloves and use RNase-free filter tips (those will also minimize the risk of RNA degradation). Work under a fume hood to prevent harmful inhalations and use suitable waste containers.
Prepare yeast lysate by mechanical disruption:
Add 600 μL of RLT buffer (containing 10 μL of β-M per 1 mL of buffer) to the cell pellets on ice and resuspend by pipetting.
Transfer the content of the tube to an autoclaved and ice-chilled 2 mL screw-cap-tube already containing 600 μL of acid-washed glass beads.
Carefully secure the lid of the tubes and lyse cells at 4°C for 10 min at max speed on a bead mill (Digital Disruptor Genie Vortex, Scientific Industries).

Critical: β-ME must be added to RLT buffer under a chemical fume hood before use (10 μL β-ME per 1 mL of RLT buffer). The mixture can be stored at RT for up to 1 month. After the mechanical disruption of the cell walls, the following steps in the purification of total RNA are performed at RT.
Note: QIAGEN recommends not processing more than ∼5 × 107 cells. Then, the above mentioned 5 OD600 units harvested as starting material (step 6) may be adjusted depending on the yeast strain background and the spectrophotometer used.
Optional: enzymatic lysis methods using zymolyase or lyticase digestion can be used instead of the mechanical disruption of cell walls (RNeasy Mini Handbook - (EN) - QIAGEN[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=14e7cf6e-521a-4cf7-8cbc-bf9f6fa33e24&lang=en]).
Transfer the lysate (usually 350 μL) to a new microcentrifuge tube.
Centrifuge 2 min at ≥ 9000×g and transfer the supernatant to a new microcentrifuge tube.
Add 1 volume of 70% ethanol.
Mix by pipetting (do not centrifuge) and proceed to step 12.
Note: Precipitates may be visible after addition of ethanol.
Transfer the sample (max 700 μL) including any precipitate that may have formed, to an RNeasy spin column placed in a 2 mL collection tube.
Centrifuge 15 s at ≥9000×g and discard the flow-through.
Note: If the sample volume exceeds 700 μL, centrifuge successive aliquots in the same column.
Add 700 μL of RW1 buffer to the RNeasy spin column.
Centrifuge 15 s at ≥9000×g to wash the spin column membrane and discard the flow-through.
Note: After centrifugation, carefully remove the RNeasy spin column from the collection tube so that the column does not contact the flow-through. Be sure to empty the collection tube completely.
Add 500 μL of RPE buffer to the RNeasy spin column.

Note: RPE buffer is supplied as a concentrate. Before using for the first time, add 4 volumes of ethanol (96%–100%) to obtain a working solution.
Centrifuge 15 s at ≥9000×g to wash the spin column membrane and discard the flow-through.
Add 500 μL of RPE buffer to the RNeasy spin column.
Centrifuge 2 min at ≥9000×g and discard the flow-through.
Note: The longer centrifugation time in in step 19 allows drying the spin column membrane, ensuring that no ethanol is carried over during RNA elution. After centrifugation, carefully remove the RNeasy spin column from the collection tube so that the column does not contact the flow-through.
Discard the collection tube and place the RNeasy spin column in a 1.5 mL RNAse-free collection tube.
Add 30–50 μL RNAse-free water directly to the spin column membrane, incubate 1 min and centrifuge 1 min at ≥9000×g to elute the RNA.
Discard the spin column and place immediately the collection tube on ice and proceed with cDNA synthesis. Problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]
Pause point: Purified RNAs can be stored at –80°C for months. However, it is strongly recommended to immediately proceed to cDNA synthesis to minimize the risk of RNA degradation due to freeze-thaw cycles.

Critical: Set up all reactions and samples on ice to minimize the risk of RNA degradation. Continue using lab coat, gloves and RNase-free filter tips.

Optional: The supplied RT primer Mix will generate random cDNAs but gene-specific primers can be used in a final concentration of 0.7 μM.

RT-qPCRs
Timing: 3 h
Analysis of the expression of FUS3 and STE2 by RT-qPCR.
RT-qPCRs were done using a StepOnePlus™ Real-Time PCR System (StepOnePlus™ Real-Time PCR System (thermofisher.com[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/order/catalog/product/4376600]) and analyzed using the Applied Biosystems® Real-Time PCR Software (Applied Biosystems® Real-Time PCR Software User Bulletin-for use with StepOne and StepOnePlus (fishersci.com[href=https://assets.fishersci.com/TFS-Assets/LSG/manuals/100023687_RTPCR_Software_UB.pdf]).
Optional: The 5S gene may be used as a control gene because it is not affected by the treatment with α-factor (see problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]).
Critical: Oligonucleotide primers must be designed so that RT-qPCR products never exceed 200 bp in length.
Prepare the following cDNA dilutions for each sample:
1/20 dilution (for FUS3 and STE2 RT-qPCRs): dilute 5 μL of cDNA into 95 μL of DNAse-free mqH2O.

1/2,000 dilution (for 5S RT-qPCR): dilute 5 μL of cDNA 1/20 dilution into 495 μL of DNAse-free mqH2O.
Use one of the undiluted cDNA samples from step 28 to prepare serial dilutions (1/5, 1/10, 1/50, 1/100, 1/500, 1/1000, 1/2000, 1/10000, 1/20000) to generate a standard curve.
Prepare the RT-qPCR master mixes on ice. Considering all samples and use a calibration curve for each primer set using volumes as listed below.

Use normalized data to calculate the statistical significance between samples of interest by using the paired-sample Student's t-test function of the Excel software or the following R-code snippet (https://www.r-project.org[href=https://www.r-project.org/]).
